subject: pfr-manager: stop pfr-manager service if PFR not supported
commitMessage:
pfr-manager: stop pfr-manager service if PFR not supported

Add support to stop the PFR manager service if PFR CPLD not available
and pfr not provisioned.

Tested:
1. When PFR CPLD is available and pfr provisioned.

Command: busctl introspect xyz.openbmc_project.PFR.Manager /xyz/
         openbmc_project/pfr
Response:
NAME                                TYPE   SIGNATURE  RESULT/VALUE FLAGS
xyz.openbmc_project.PFR.Attributes interface  -          -
.UfmLocked                          property  b          false
.UfmProvisioned                     property  b          true
.UfmSupport                         property  b          true

2. When PFR CPLD not available.

PFR service has been stopped.
Command: busctl tree xyz.openbmc_project.PFR.Manager.service
Response: No objects discovered.

CPLD version is displayed.
Command: GET: https://<BMC_IP/redfish/v1/UpdateService/FirmwareInventory
              /cpld_active
Response:
{
    "@odata.id": "/redfish/v1/UpdateService/FirmwareInventory/
                 cpld_active",
    "@odata.type": "#SoftwareInventory.v1_1_0.SoftwareInventory",
    "Description": "Other image",
    "Id": "cpld_active",
    "Name": "Software Inventory",
    "Status": {
        "Health": "OK",
        "HealthRollup": "OK",
        "State": "Enabled"
    },
    "Updateable": false,
    "Version": "0.7"
}

3. When PFR CPLD available and PFR not provisioned.
PFR service has been stopped.
Command: busctl tree xyz.openbmc_project.PFR.Manager.service
Response: No objects discovered.

CPLD version is displayed.
Command: GET: https://<BMC_IP/redfish/v1/UpdateService/FirmwareInventory
              /cpld_active
Response:
{
    "@odata.id": "/redfish/v1/UpdateService/FirmwareInventory/
                  cpld_active",
    "@odata.type": "#SoftwareInventory.v1_1_0.SoftwareInventory",
    "Description": "Other image",
    "Id": "cpld_active",
    "Name": "Software Inventory",
    "Status": {
        "Health": "OK",
        "HealthRollup": "OK",
        "State": "Enabled"
    },
    "Updateable": false,
    "Version": "44.0-2.0-
    508eaac356f28be18791eb6027a663b01dcfbe3101bc2777ccfb9101289b97c5"
}

Signed-off-by: Chalapathi Venkataramashetty <chalapathix.venkataramashetty@intel.com>
Change-Id: I93945033df6f4381923000973e57f346dad87e30

Patch Set 5:

(4 comments)

Tested this patch on a platform with unresponsive PFR CPLD. It successfully silences the repeated journal messages :), but only because the process never starts in the first place due to the invalid service dependencies :(.
Seems like this implementation could be simplified a lot.

Patch Set 11:

(7 comments)

I tested this out by checking out this commit, and replacing the contents of stopService() with "exit(EXIT_SUCCESS);". Since my platform does not have working PFR CPLD, here is the service status:

     Active: inactive (dead) since Tue 2021-01-26 00:50:41 UTC; 2min 31s left
    Process: 369 ExecStart=/usr/bin/pfr-manager (code=exited, status=0/SUCCESS)
   Main PID: 369 (code=exited, status=0/SUCCESS)

... systemd[1]: Starting Daemon manages PFR dbus properties and Event logs...
... pfr-manager[369]: Intel PFR service started successfully
... systemd[1]: Started Daemon manages PFR dbus properties and Event logs.
... pfr-manager[369]: Failed to find the GPIO line:
... pfr-manager[369]: Failed to read GPIO line:
... pfr-manager[369]: Exception caught in readCPLDVersion.
... pfr-manager[369]: PFR-CPLD not present.
... pfr-manager[369]: Exception caught in getProvisioningStatus.
... systemd[1]: xyz.openbmc_project.PFR.Manager.service: Succeeded.

I don't know why you would see activating/auto-restart. Maybe you were exiting before the application gets a D-Bus name? In which case, it's never considered started. Exiting from inside stopService works well for me.

    Process: 12928 ExecStart= (code=exited, status=0/SUCCESS)
   Main PID: 12928 (code=exited, status=0/SUCCESS)

Jan 27 04:11:00 intel-obmc pfr-manager[12928]: CHALA in main()... 27th Jan..
Jan 27 04:11:00 intel-obmc pfr-manager[12928]: Intel PFR service started successfully
Jan 27 04:11:00 intel-obmc systemd[1]: Started Daemon manages PFR dbus properties and Event logs.
Jan 27 04:11:00 intel-obmc phosphor-mapper[253]: Introspect call failed with error: generic:53, Invalid request descriptor on process: xyz.openbmc_project.PFR.Manager path: /
Jan 27 04:11:01 intel-obmc pfr-manager[12928]: Failed to find the GPIO line:
Jan 27 04:11:01 intel-obmc pfr-manager[12928]: Failed to read GPIO line:

Jan 27 04:11:06 intel-obmc systemd[1]: xyz.openbmc_project.PFR.Manager.service: Scheduled restart job, restart counter is at 11.

Jan 27 04:11:06 intel-obmc systemd[1]: Starting Daemon manages PFR dbus properties and Event logs...

Patch Set 12:

Why is GPIO read is failing? CPLD version GPIOs should be able to read always despite PFR or non-PFR CPLD.
Jan 27 04:11:01 intel-obmc pfr-manager[12928]: Failed to find the GPIO line:
Jan 27 04:11:01 intel-obmc pfr-manager[12928]: Failed to read GPIO line:
Jan 27 04:11:01 intel-obmc pfr-manager[12928]: Exception caught in readCPLDVersion.

Patch Set 12:

> Patch Set 12:
> 
> Why is GPIO read is failing? CPLD version GPIOs should be able to read always despite PFR or non-PFR CPLD.
> Jan 27 04:11:01 intel-obmc pfr-manager[12928]: Failed to find the GPIO line:
> Jan 27 04:11:01 intel-obmc pfr-manager[12928]: Failed to read GPIO line:
> Jan 27 04:11:01 intel-obmc pfr-manager[12928]: Exception caught in readCPLDVersion.

We have only Main PLD lines are defined and PLD lines are not defined in our platform. Hence GPIO read is failing for them. Thank You

This is a new error. Possibly caused by putting the CPLD version detection before starting the event loop? Might need a fix similar to a9bf9717.

> Jan 27 04:11:01 intel-obmc pfr-manager[12928]: Failed to find the GPIO line:
> Jan 27 04:11:01 intel-obmc pfr-manager[12928]: Failed to read GPIO line:

> Jan 27 04:11:06 intel-obmc systemd[1]: Stopped Daemon manages PFR dbus properties and Event logs.
> Jan 27 04:11:06 intel-obmc systemd[1]: Starting Daemon manages PFR dbus properties and Event logs...

This is what I see when I test with Restart=always. Are you sure there's no persistent configuration overriding the Restart policy? What is the output of "systemctl cat xyz.openbmc_project.PFR.Manager" and "systemctl show xyz.openbmc_project.PFR.Manager | grep Restart"?

Its hard to review this code. Please split this commit in to 3 atleast.
1) Exposure UFM support property over dbus.
2) read cpld_active and update value to settings service.
3) Read i2c bus & slave address from config and stop pfr-manager service, if CPLD not present or PFR not provisioned.

Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 29b4779eb8dd444f2e70806e35ae2c398222a74d by AppaRao Puli
Think this needs to be changed to on failure to not have it restart automatically
Done
Is there any systemd API alternative available instead of system() ?  I also don't know available or not.
Ack. checking for alternative.
Implemented. Thank You
Do you need to return from here ?
Ack.
included return. Thank You
Why there is no check to stop the service here ?
Ack. checking regarding this.
These properties are updated during the service creation. We stop the service after by checking PFR support and PFR object in Entity Manager. Thank You
Do we need to add check here also to stop the service ? Or system has to be rebooted whenever the provisioning status changed ?
checking for provisioning status is done when the host or chassis changes its state. PFR service check is done as soon as the service starts/restarts.

Why do you want to stop service if PFR is not provisioned?

Did you checked external interfaces(Redfish) for reporting the PFR "Not provisioned" state correctly in this case?
Updated. PFR service is stopped when PFR not supported. PFR provisioning status is reported in /Systems/system in redfish. Updated the commit message. Thank You.
3. PFR Supported platform but "PFR unProvisioned"
Updated this test case. Thank You
I think this is fixed now.  Can you attempt to pull that patch(as separate patch though)?

There is a systemd D-Bus method to stop a service. I would think that would be preferable to starting a new systemctl process.

But, this seems unnecessary - why can't you just exit(0)? I briefly tested it and saw no bad effects from just exiting. Systemd does not restart the program (since we have Restart=on-failure), and it just shows it as "inactive (dead)"
Ack, Verified that exit(0) alone not serving the purpose, systemd is restarting the service with status as Active: activating (auto-restart).

You can use D-Bus method call to perform the stop service.

busctl call org.freedesktop.systemd1 /org/freedesktop/systemd1 org.freedesktop.systemd1.Manager StartUnit ss <service file> "replace";
Implemented. Thank You

Can you explain to me why exit(0) doesn't work? I don't understand because in my tests it does work fine, and that's exactly what Restore=on-failure is supposed to allow. Besides being simpler to implement, I think it's better that the application does not assume it's running as a systemd service to work correctly - debugging is easier in some cases when you can just run the application from the console.
Ack

Tested several times with std::exit (EXIT_SUCCESS), and Restart=on-failure, on-abnormal, on-watchdog, Service restarted with below service status after exit(0).
systemctl status xyz.openbmc_project.PFR.Manager.service

     Active: activating (auto-restart)
    Process: 4434 ExecStart= <process_location> (code=exited, status=0/SUCCESS)
   Main PID: 4434 (code=exited, status=0/SUCCESS)

I would like know your implementation and testing procedure and environment. Thank You.
I have been meaning to test it again and reply with the steps, but haven't had time. Sorry :) will try to do it next week if this is not urgent, otherwise, don't wait for me.

duplciate code. Write a common API to stop the service. 

In fact you can use the systemd call which is provided above.
Updated. Thank You
Need to exit in this case also? When I tested this patch, pfr::getProvisioningStatus returns -1 because the CPLD does not respond at all. PFR is certainly not supported in that case, right?
if i2c operation failed due to some other reason other than CPLD not responding then stopping the service is not recommended. Thank You
If the CPLD does not respond, then getProvisioningStatus returns -1. So we should stop the program right?
Stopping the service if getProvisioningStatus returns -1. Thank You
Done
Why do you need to find the baseboard at all? Why not just call GetSubTree for xyz.openbmc_project.Configuration.PFR interface to find the PFR object?
Ack. Thank You

Shouldn't this be done after checking that PFR is supported? If the CPLD doesn't respond, what does readCPLDVersion() return and do you really want to write that to cpld_active object?
Modified. We need to read the MainPLD and PLD values from gpio lines even when we have non-PFR CPLD which is been taken care in main(). Thank You
OK, I see. But there's no need to call it twice, right? In PS 12, you added another call which I think can be removed since the one in main will cover it.

calling updateCPLDversion() in main() is required when we have non-pfr CPLD to update the mainPLD and PLD from GPIOs. calling updateCPLDversion() after PFR supported is required to update the RoT, SVN and CPLD Hash. Thank You,

But on a PFR CPLD, aren't those items (RoT/SVN/Hash) going to be read during the initial call from main()? Is there some state change done in the CPLD which would result in different values being returned the second time?
On PFR CPLD, I have observed an exception while reading the cpld version from main() as i2cBus and i2cAddress are zero. Hence during second time, RoT, SVN and Hash are updated. Thank You
Ok I understand it better now. I think you had it right before I started this comment thread. Sorry for giving bad advice.

Setting PFR CPLD version and checking for PFR CPLD to stop service are async operations. Its not guaranteed to be setting CPLD version executes before force stoping PFR service. So this need to serialized.
Re ordered. CPLD version is updated before checkPFRandAddObjects() completes. Thank You

I'm not totally sure how libpfr is used (is it supposed to be used by other applications?), but these definitions should probably go in libpfr/src/pfr.cpp, since the declarations are in libpfr/inc/pfr.hpp
defined in libpfr/src/pfr.cpp. Thank You

Now that I think about it a little more, if libpfr is meant to be used by multiple applications, then this won't work well. Every application linking with libpfr would have to implement the same entity-manager search to find the I2C configuration, or else it won't be able to talk to the PFR PLD. I don't know what was the vision for libpfr so someone else will have to decide how to resolve this.

Implementation of entity-manager search for I2C Configuration is moved to libpfr on a separate patch(https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/pfr-manager/+/41663) and does not depend on application.
